Gynaecology treats women’s reproductive health. Our Department provides advanced diagnostics (colposcopy, hysteroscopy, USG, biopsy) and preventive and therapeutic management of adolescent gynecological disorders, fertility issues,stress urinary continence,uterine prolapse, fibroids, menopausal disorders,uterine bleeding,  and gynaecological cancers.The Gynaecology staff is well-equipped to manage modern gynecological treatments like laparoscopy and hysteroscopy.

Why choose Hope Hospitals for Gynaecology?

To serve the patients with quality care and service, the department is staffed by a group of physicians, surgeons, doctors, and technicians with extensive training and expertise. They offer people suffering from gynaecological issues top-notch care and long-lasting healing.Our contemporary birthing suites provide the newest technologies for a safe and comfortable birth.

Our gynaecologists provide 24-hour nursing care to emergency and labor patients.We give compassionate treatment tailored to you and your family since every woman is different.Gynecology specialists at Hope Hospital offer early detection, precise diagnosis, and outpatient treatments for both common and difficult problems of the female reproductive system.

Services we offer for Gynecology

  • Breast soreness, tumors, or other modifications
  • Mental health
  • Hormone and endocrine health
  • Infections, such as yeast infection
  • Unusual bleeding or periods
  • Bladder control issues
  • Symptoms of menopause like hot flashes
  • Period cramps
  • Pelvic floor conditions
  • Pelvic pain
  • Pregnancy preparation
  • Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)
  • Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS)
  • Endometriosis
  • Uterine fibroids

Treatment for Gynaecology

  • Endometrial ablation  is a minimally invasive surgical method for treating severe menstrual bleeding (periods). The endometrium, the tissue that lines the uterus, is abated (destroyed) during the process.
  • Laparoscopic surgery is a surgical technique known as laparoscopy enables a surgeon to access the belly (tummy) and pelvis from the inside without having to make significant skin incisions.
  • Hormone replacement therapy Female hormones are present in medications used for hormone replacement therapy. You take the drug to replenish the lost estrogen caused by menopause. Hot flashes and vaginal soreness are two common menopausal symptoms that are most frequently treated with hormone therapy.
  • Colposcopy  is a test to examine your cervix more closely. The cervix is the gap between your vagina and womb. If a cervical screening reveals alterations in your cells brought on by specific forms of human papillomavirus, a colposcopy is frequently performed (HPV). Cervical cancer cells may develop from these altered cells.
  • Endometrial biopsy is done for the purpose of diagnosing cancer and other cellular abnormalities, a biopsy of the uterine lining (the endometrium) is often taken. The process aids in determining why a woman is bleeding excessively or inconsistently.
  • Hysteroscopy is an operation to look inside the womb (uterus). The procedure is performed with the use of a hysteroscope, a kind of slender telescope outfitted with a light and camera.
  • Hysterectomy The womb is surgically removed during a hysterectomy (uterus). After the procedure, you won’t be able to become pregnant again. No matter your age, if you haven’t previously experienced the menopause, you won’t have periods anymore. Women between 40 to 50 are more likely to experience it.
  • Pelvic laparoscopy Surgery to inspect the pelvic organs is known as a laparoscopy. Additionally, the operation is utilized to treat several pelvic organ problems.

Minimally Invasive Gynecologic surgery (MIGS) In comparison to open surgery, minimally invasive gynecologic procedures including hysteroscopic and laparoscopic procedures are associated with a quicker recovery, a shorter hospital stay, less pain, less scarring, and fewer infections.

Do all gynaecologists also do obstetrics?

Obstetrics focuses especially on providing treatment for expectant mothers. Most gynaecologists are also obstetricians because the field of gynaecology covers practically all facets of a woman’s reproductive health from puberty through menopause and beyond. Any pain, discomfort, or infection in the uterus, genitalia, or breasts should be treated by a gynaecologist. In addition, gynaecologists can help with concerns about infertility and contraception.

 

Expectations for obstetrician-gynaecologist appointments?

Vital signs, medication lists, and a brief medical history are typically the first things your doctor asks you. Open-ended inquiries that need to be answered come next.

In-depth inquiries about pelvic pain, menstrual cycles, sexual history, fertility problems, bowel or bladder dysfunction, and any unexpected physical changes will be the main focus of your obstetric gynaecologist. The pelvic exam will usually come last because it is the most delicate component of the physical examination, followed by the breast and stomach exams.

 

What advantages do laparoscopic procedures offer?

The less-painful incisions are smaller. As a result, there is less need for painkillers, a quicker recovery, and better cosmetic outcomes. In addition to being able to eat whenever they feel like it, patients can return to work sooner and experience less internal scarring, hernias, and infection risk.

 

How long does it take to recover from gynaecology laparoscopic surgery?

Based on the patient and the type of gynaecological laparoscopic surgery, this is typically customized. The majority of women need pain medication for a week after laparoscopic surgery. For 4-6 weeks, it may be advised to refrain from sexual activity, bathing in a tub, douching, vigorous exercise, or heavy lifting. If their employment is not physically demanding, many patients opt to resume their jobs within two weeks.

 

What causes periods to be irregular?

The most frequent causes of this are polycystic ovarian syndrome and obesity.

 

What caused my periods to resume after menopause?

Sonography and blood tests are required before you can examine the cause of your menstruation.
